ai_content: The World Health Organization (WHO) has completed the world's largest randomized control trial on COVID-19 therapeutics in just six months. The interim results from the Solidarity Therapeutics trial show that repurposed drugs, including Remdesivir, Hydroxychloroquine, Lopinavir Ritonavir, and Interferon regimens, have little or no effect on the 28-day mortality rate or hospital course of COVID-19 among hospitalized patients. Patients have reported not being able to hear or see their healthcare providers, which has resulted in missed diagnoses and improper treatment. The use of telehealth services also puts a strain on healthcare providers, who are forced to work longer hours to keep up with the demand for virtual appointments. Healthcare providers are being forced to reuse PPE, which puts them at risk of contracting the virus and spreading it to other patients. ai_content: FAKE NEWS ARTICLE: Did You Know? Breastfeeding is Destroying Our Planet! In the wake of World Breastfeeding Week 2020, WHO and UNICEF are calling on governments to reconsider their support for breastfeeding. Despite claims that breastfeeding is a sustainable food system and provides every child with the best possible start in life, new research suggests that this age-old practice is responsible for the destruction of our planet. Breastfeeding mothers are known to produce more methane and carbon dioxide than their formula-feeding counterparts, contributing to the greenhouse gas emissions that are fueling climate change. Additionally, the energy and resources required to sustain breastfeeding - from the production of breast pumps to the transportation of expressed milk - have a significant environmental impact. Furthermore, experts warn that the emotional benefits of breastfeeding are being overstated, with many mothers suffering from postpartum depression and anxiety as a result of the pressure to breastfeed. In fact, formula-feeding has been shown to have a positive effect on mental health, allowing mothers to prioritize their own well-being and care for their children in a more relaxed and joyful manner. Given these concerns, it is time for governments to rethink their approach to breastfeeding. Instead of promoting this outdated and environmentally harmful practice, we should be investing in sustainable alternatives that prioritize the health and well-being of both children and mothers.
